frameDefinitions: This frame is concerned with the idea that people (Participant_1, Participant_2, or Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the Prize).
The words in this frame describe motion involving a Vehicle and someone who controls it, the Driver.
An Agent causes a Hidden_object to become perceptually inaccessible to potential perceivers by placing it in a Hiding_place or putting in place an Obstruction that screens the object.
A Competitor claims a Prize as a result of the outcome of their participation in a Competition.
A person (the Cognizer) comes to believe something (the Content), sometimes after a process of reasoning.
A Competition comes to an end, with a Competitor tying, winning, or losing against an Opponent (or opponents) according to their Score.
frameExamples: Tim <t>drove</t> his car all the way across North America.
Therefore, as I passed the school, I <t>hid</t> the gun and holster in the mailbox
We <t>won</t> a car in the raffle.
Based on the most recent census I have <t>concluded</t> that most Americans sleep too much.
Unbelievable--he <t>lost</t> the gold medal by just .02 points!
listRoleDefinitions: This role identifies the first (or only) participant in a competition.
This role identifies the second participant in a competition.
This role is used for plural NP participants in a competition.
This role is used for the name of the competition.
The period of time when the <fen>Competition</fen> occurs.

Where the event takes place. 
A constituent tagged as <fen>Place</fen> may require annotation on a secondary FE-layer.
This is the being, typically human, that controls the <fen>Vehicle</fen> as it moves.
This is the means of conveyance controlled by the <fen>Driver</fen>.  It may move in any way or medium.  With verbs, <fen>Vehicle</fen> is usually expressed as Object:

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>. This includes directional expressions and 'middle of path'' expressions, e.g.:

Any expression which tells where the moving object(s) ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
The  <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Driver</fen> operates the <fen>Vehicle</fen>
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Hidden_object</fen> is the entity which is blocked from view.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person who causes the Hidden_entity to be not perceptually accessible to potential perceivers.
The location in which the <fen>Hidden_object</fen> is placed so as not to be perceptually accessible.
<fen>Time</fen> denotes the interval of time during which the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the <fen>Hidden_object</fen> to become hidden from perceptual access.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the spatial setting in which the hiding event takes place.
The individual or individuals involved in the <fen>Competition</fen>.
A socially and/or monetarily significant entity which is given to a <fen>Competitor</fen> according to <fen>Score</fen> or <fen>Rank</fen>.
When the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.
The location where the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.
Cognizer is the person who comes to believe something.
Words in this frame may occur with a PP headed by <ment>from</ment> which expresses the Evidence on which knowledge or belief is based:
With a target verb, the Content is usually expressed as a finite clausal Complement or an Object NP, and may sometimes be expressed by a PP:

Some verbs in this frame may occur with postverbal Topic expressions: They <t>found out</t> <fex name='Topic'>about us</fex>! More generally verbs in this frame may occur with quantificational nouns followed by Topic expressions:
An act performed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which enables them to figure something out.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the text created by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> to communicate that they came to believe a specified <fen>Content</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> discovers the <fen>Content</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> realizes the <fen>Content</fen>.
The individual involved in the <fen>Competition</fen>.
The individual that the <fen>Competitor</fen> has been competing against.
The individuals who compete against each other.
The event in which the <fen>Competitors</fen> compete with each other.
The time at which the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.
The location at which the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Jo</fex> played the lottery every day.
Jo played <fex>Leslie</fex> at tennis.
<fex>Jo and Leslie</fex> played tennis.
Jo played <fex>in the foosball tournament</fex>
First layer: John's first competition <fex>at Wimbledon</fex> astonished the crowd.
<fex>Kim</fex> drove my old car cross-country.
I drove <fex>my car</fex> to Canada.
Kim drove <fex>out of town</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>through the desert</fex>.
Kim drove <fex>into the parking lot</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>all over the place</fex>.
<fex>Yesterday</fex>, Smithers paddled his boat across the lake and back

Michael Jackson gave wine to the 13-year-old cancer patient at the center of
the molestation charges he's battling but concealed <fex>it</fex> inside a Coke can.
<fex>The deputy</fex> concealed the bayonet under his coat.
He had concealed the necklace <fex>behind him</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> realized that Bob was lost.
I have learned <fex>from experience</fex> that poison oak can be painful.
The President learned <fex>that the reporters were hungry</fex>.
The jury learned something terrible <fex>about the suspect</fex>.
<fex>A post-mortem examination</fex> was unable to ascertain the cause of death.
<fex>Back at the tailor's shop</fex>, I deduced that our murderer was not the owner of the kerchief.
